thread.section_title: Palm Beach County High School Sports - Sun Sentinel
thread.title: State run ends as Oxbridge falls to Jones in OT
thread.title_full: State run ends as Oxbridge falls to Jones in OT - Sun Sentinel

author: Bill Kemp
title: State run ends as Oxbridge falls to Jones in OT
text:
Oxbridge Academy held a 15-point lead and then it all slipped away.
Oxbridge went scoreless for more than 11 minutes and ended up dropping a 57-56 overtime Class 5A girls basketball state semifinal game to Orlando Jones on Wednesday at the Lakeland Center.
"We just weren't hitting our shots," Oxbridge coach Traci Wolfe said. "Our motto is 'fourth-quarter strong,' specifically. That is our best quarter, but we didn't hit shots. It wasn't a matter of being gassed."
Jones will face Tallahassee Florida High in the Florida 5A title game Saturday. Florida High advanced after beating Cardinal Gibbons 48-43 earlier in the day.
Oxbridge (23-6) held a 47-32 lead with 1:11 remaining in the third quarter and then the ThunderWolves' shooting went ice cold, allowing Jones to go on a 20-0 run and eventually push the game into overtime.
"We were forcing a little bit. We struggled to put together four quarters all year. That's our goal and that seems to be what our struggle is, that we have three-great quarters and one-bad quarter. All of our losses this season have been a result of what you have seen today," Wolfe said.
Oxbridge was outscored 14-0 in the fourth quarter and did not score again until sophomore guard Aaliyah Stanley canned a free throw with 1:11 remaining in OT, closing Jones' lead to 52-48.
Jones coach Robert Moultrie said his fourth-quarter message to his team was simple, and in the third quarter, he also scrapped playing zone defense.
"The message was everything to the goal on offense. Let's get to the goal. We are going to attack the rim. And on defense, we were just going to take it one possession at a time and what happens, happens. We were going to rebound and attack the basket."
Oxbridge actually held a 16-point lead at one point with less than six minutes remaining in the third and after Haley Race hit a free throw with 1:11 left in the third, the scoring drought started.
"We have never faced a 16-point deficit and came back, we've never done that. We've come pretty close (to shutting a team out in a quarter). We've have never shut a team out of that caliber," Moultrie said.
Trailing by three points in the closing seconds of overtime, Stanley elected to drive to the basket, hoping to draw a foul and convert a three-point play â€“ instead of pulling up for a 3-point shot. She scored but drew no foul as the game ended, 57-56.
"I was going for the foul," Stanley said. "It was me that gave up that game. Letting them comeback was a mistake. Defensively, rebounding, we were challenged. It was a hard game."
Stanley, who made several acrobatic drives to the basket, finished with 15 points. Alex Zaph led Oxbridge with 17 points and six rebounds while guard Nasha Gilbert-Taylor added 11 points and nine boards.
Jones was led by Chardell Jones with 21 points and hauled down 12 rebounds while Shania Jacobs added 15.
 Basketball
